metadata.title: Synthesis strategies and potential applications of metal-organic frameworks for electrode materials for rechargeable lithium ion batteries

Review
Synthesis strategies and potential applications of metal-organic frameworks for electrode materials for rechargeable lithium ion batteries
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ccr.2019.02.030 0010-8545/ 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: shiwei@nankai.edu.cn (W. Shi), pcheng@nankai.edu.cn (P. Cheng).
Lin Zhang, Hongwen Liu, Wei Shi ⇑, Peng Cheng ⇑ Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Material Chemistry (MOE), Renewable Energy Conversion and Storage Center, College of Chemistry, Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 6 December 2018 Received in revised form 2 February 2019 Accepted 23 February 2019
Keywords: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) MOF-related nanomaterials Rational design Synthetic strategies Electrode materials Lithium ion batteries
a b s t r a c t
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are acknowledged as a new generation of porous materials and have attracted great interest because of the controllable structures, tunable properties and diverse applications for gas storage, catalysis, magnetism, sensing and drug delivery. Recently, MOFs have been proved outstanding candidates of electrochemical energy storage materials. Their chemical compositions and structures can be tuned at the molecular level and inherently porous framework can facilitate fast mass transportation. In this review, principles and strategies for the rational design of MOFs and MOFrelated nanomaterials for electrochemical energy storage are systematically summarized. Furthermore, this review is also structured to cover recent progress of MOFs and MOF-related nanomaterials and their potential applications for rechargeable lithium ion batteries.
2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Today, large consumption of fossil fuels and consequent environmental pollution have become an urgent global problem. The pursuit of clean energy and effective energy storage and conversion systems has been one of the main subjects of current attention. Free solar energy and wind energy are clean, safe, and renewable candidates to replace non-renewable fuel sources, whereas they are applicable and competitive only if effective and reliable energy storage technologies are well developed because of their intermittent nature. Electrochemical energy storage (EES) is regarded as one of the most promising methods for such intermittent energy storage [1–3]. Among various EES devices, rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have received great attention and undergone fast development during the last 40 years because of their high operation potential and energy density, light mass, long life, high-rate capability, and environmental friendliness [4,5]. However, LIBs still have the limitations of capacities, rate performance, cycle life and safety for practical applications. To increase the energy storage and conversion performance, rational designs and synthesis of new electrode materials and assembling them into the devices have become a research challenge [6,7].
Composed by metal nodes and organic linkers, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a new generation of porous materials and have attracted great interest in the last few years [8,9]. Tremendous efforts have been made on the studies of multifunctional MOFs and their applications for gas storage and separation, catalysis, magnetism, sensing and drug delivery [10–14]. Yet the application of MOFs for lithium storage is burgeoning recently because both the diverse frameworks and the pore structures could be favorable to the storage of lithium [15–17]. By rational design, diverse MOFs can be synthesized for targeted structures and properties [18,19]. The compositions and MOF structures can be adjusted by well-designed inorganic as well as organic building blocks with tuning the synthetic conditions or by post-synthetic modifications and the morphologies of MOFs can be fine-tuned to exhibit high intensity, ultrahigh surface area, and favorable chemical activity [20,21]. Moreover, due to the high porosity and surface areas, MOFs can act as supports to load active nanomaterials to
Fig. 1. MOF-related material
form nanoparticle/MOF composites or as sacrificial materials to derive various nanostructures through different treatment methods. Such MOF-based nanomaterials can reserve the unique function of each component and generate synergistic effects to conquer the disadvantages of each individual counterpart, the limitations of insufficient electronic conductivity and then in turn to enhance chemical stability for energy storage applications [22–24].
There are important reviews have summarized the previous investigations of MOFs for EES. An account of the up-to-date progress focused on MOF-derived materials, taking advantage of MOFs as template/sacrificial materials for electrochemical properties [25]. A detailed appraisement of MOFs and MOF derivatives for supercapacitors and LIBs was published recently [26]. An overview regarding the transition-metal (Fe, Co, Ni) based MOFs and their derived materials for supercapacitors and LIBs applications gained much attention [27]. The emerging applications of MOF-related materials for EES and their advantages and limitations were highlighted [28]. Despite these considerable advancements in the electrochemical application of MOFs, herein, we present a comprehensive review to cover the principles and strategies for the design and construction of MOF-based/derived materials with target properties, especially for their recent progress in the field of rechargeable LIBs. This review will highlight the major hurdles and their prospective solutions, thus providing a criterion for future study in this highly significative area (Fig. 1).

sections.heading: 2. Basics and preparations of MOF-related materials
sections.text:
MOFs are crystalline and porous materials assembled by metal nodes with organic linkers [8,9]. By the well-designed metal centers and functional linkers, MOFs can have specific structures with higher surface areas, well-defined pore sizes and desired functionalities, which are highly satisfactory for developments of electrode materials for LIBs. Moreover, MOFs can serve as supports to load active nanomaterials or as sacrificial materials to derive different nanostructures for enhanced lithium storage performance [22–24]. Herein, the rational design and preparation of MOFs, MOF-based composites and MOF-derived materials will be highlighted.
s for LIBs in EES devices.

sections.heading: 2.1. Design strategies
sections.text:
Constructed from metal centers and organic linkers, MOFs can be rationally modulated to obtain expected structures and specific functionalities for particular applications [18,19]. In general, lithium-ion storage performance of MOFs is related to their particle size, pore size, active surface area, crystallinity and functional groups with redox-active sites and conductivity. Thus, constructing MOFs with high surface area could provide the maximum exposure to the electrolyte, and the suitable pore sizes of MOFs would be beneficial for high flow rates of the electrolyte. Furthermore, high porosity and crystallinity of MOFs provide the access of large lithium-ion accommodation numbers and structural stability, which are important factors for lithium storage [29,30]. Based on the component and structure features of MOFs, a powerful way for increased specific capacity is the introduction of redox-active sites on both metal centers and the ligands [31,32]. The morphology of MOFs could have impact on the surface area, the number of active sites and ion kinetics, which could also influence their electrochemical performance accordingly. For example, MOF nanospheres showed better performance which can be attributed to their large specific surfaces that could provide a large number of reaction sites, and their unique structures could not only reduce the diffusion length of Li+, but also accommodate huge structural deformation than other nanostructures [33,34].
Apart from the direct use, the unique structure of MOFs allows the combination of specific species with MOFs to endow the resulting material with excellent electrochemical performance [35]. For example, MOFs can act as templates to include nanoparticles into their pores or skeleton, forming nanoparticle/MOF composites. The combined effect derived from nanoparticle/MOF can lead to new physical and chemical properties and superior applications in lithium storage applications that could not be accessible by any single-component material [36].
Furthermore, the unique compositions and structures enable MOFs to be regarded as sacrificial templates for ordered nanostructured materials and high surface area, such as metal oxides (MOs), nanocarbon and MO@C composites via thermally-induced approaches. Facile heating treatment of MOFs in air gives rise to framework decomposition but produces high surface area MOs [37]. MOFs with high surface areas provide access to high surface area hollow core–shell MO nanostructures through facile thermal methods, as shown in (Fig. 2a) [38]. Likewise, appropriate heating methods can lead to carbon-coated M/MO materials that are
Fig. 2. (a) Preparation procedure of hierarchical multi-shelled and multi-compositional Copyright 2013 American Chemical Society. (b) Preparation procedure and nitrogen (N Reprinted with permission from Ref. [40]. Copyright 2014 American Chemical Society.
suitable for electrochemical applications. Nanocarbon materials have also been obtained from the carbonization of MOFs at elevated temperatures under inert atmosphere and used for electrochemical applications [39]. Highly porous MOFs can be the precursor for nanocarbons with high surface areas, whereas carbons derived by non-porous MOF often have low surface area (Fig. 2b) [40]. Compared with other templates, MOFs have the advantages related to their morphology and porosity, which could be preserved in MOF-derived nanomaterials to result in high-performance electrochemical properties [41,42]. In general, well-designed MOFs can provide the opportunity for MOF-derived nanostructures with targeted properties rather than hit or miss results, thus rendering MOF-derived nanomaterials to be the ideal candidates for electrochemical applications.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis methods
sections.text: By rational design with optimized synthesis method, MOFs with desired structures and functionalities can be achieved. In addition, different treatments of MOFs as templates or precursors allow the formation of nanoparticle/MOF composites for direct use or derivation of various nanomaterials [18,19,22–24].

sections.heading: 2.2.1. MOFs
sections.text:
The construction of MOFs can be affected by a series of synthesis conditions, such as the solvent, the reaction temperature, pH value. Generally, there are four primary methods for the preparation of MOFs, including direct reaction in solution, hydrothermal/ solvothermal synthesis, microwave/ultrasound-assisted synthesis and electrochemical synthesis.
2.2.1.1. Direct reaction in solution. Some specific MOFs can be synthesized by directly mixing the starting material at room temperature in solution, which is explored as one of the high output synthesis methods for MOFs. The reaction conditions also have significant influence on the structure, the size and morphology of MOFs. For example, Huang and co-workers applied a direct reaction in solution to obtain MOF-5, through introducing amine by direct mixing [43]. They demonstrated that fast introduction of amine played a critical role in the quick formation of nuclei, which was favorable for the further formation of the nanocrystals. Wee et al. proposed an approach for the synthesis of nano-sized HKUST-1, ([Cu3(BTC)2]n, H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and IRMOF-3 in two ways: (1) Freezing the reaction mixture in
MO microboxes with MOFs precursors. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [38]. 2) adsorption isotherms of carbon derivatives from porous and non-porous MOFs.
liquid N2, following a freeze drying process; (2) by cooling the solution of the reagents prior to their mixing. The crystal sizes of the resultant HKUST-1 and IRMOF-3 by way-1 were 100 nm and 150 nm, respectively. HKUST-1 obtained by way-2 have a broader particle size distribution in comparison with that obtained by way-1 [44].
Growing single crystal of MOFs is important for the structural analysis. Slow reaction is beneficial for the single crystal formation. However, the reaction rates of the metal ions and organic linkers are usually high. To slow the reaction, diffusion controlled reaction performed in a test tube allows slow diffusion and convective mixing of two reagent solutions in the top and bottom of the tube between an inert intermediate layer, to create crystal nucleus. In this condition, the concentration gradient between the reagents usually results in large crystals. In comparison with the above mentioned direct reaction, the slow diffusion efficiently avoided defect generation due to the slow interfacial reaction between the two immiscible reagent phases. For example, the MOF ([Cu(BDC)(DMF)]n, DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide) nanosheets formed in a three-layer diffusion reaction which composed of a topmost solution of Cu(NO3)2 in a mixture of DMF and CH3CN and a bottom of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2BDC) in DMF and CH3CN, separated by the intermediate layer of a mixture of DMF and CH3CN. Under static condition, the reaction solutions diffused into the intermediate layer and gave rise to a slow growth of thin MOF nanosheets (Fig. 3) [45]. In addition, increasing the synthesis temperature enables variation of the thickness of the nanosheets from average thickness <10 nm) to 30–500 nm. Moreover, this synthesis method can be modulated to develop various other types of nanosheets by substituting Cu2+ and BDC2- for alternative metal ions and dicarboxylate linkers.
2.2.1.2. Hydrothermal/solvothermal synthesis. MOFs have been generally prepared via hydro/solvo-thermal conditions, in which the metal salt, organic linker and optional templating agent are mixed with solvent and then heated under pressure in autoclaves. These methods have been proved as powerful ways to accelerate the
discovery of new MOFs. For example, a high-yield synthesis of the well-known MOF-5 with high surface area, constructed through Zn4O core linked with H2BDC, was developed by heating a mixture of N,N-diethylformamide (DEF), Zn(NO3)2 4H2O and H2BDC at 105 C in a closed vessel [46]. IRMOF-3, NH2-functionalized MOF-5, were constructed by a similar solvothermal method: Zn(NO3)2 6H2O and NH2-functionalized H2BDC (H2BDC-NH2) were dissolved in DMF or DEF and heated at 90 C for 24 h to produce IRMOF-3 with yields of 90% and 70% for DMF and DEF, respectively [47].
The synthetic conditions (e.g. pH value, solvent, concentration and ratio of the reactants, metal ion, counter ion, reaction temperature and reaction time) can greatly affect the crystallization process [48]. To achieve high yield and high phase purity of the MOFs, these conditions have to be optimized according to the basic principles of coordination chemistry. MIL-101, Cr3O(F/OH) (H2O)2[C6H4(CO2)2]3, was prepared hydrothermally using Cr (NO3)3 9H2O and H2BDC with the addition of HF at 220 C for 8 h [49]. However, purifying MIL-101 remained an issue since the impurity phases often resulted in low yield and BrunauerEmmett-Teller (BET) surface areas. A temperature-programmed process can promote to generate large carboxylic acid impurities which were easily to isolate from the pure MIL-101; [50] the aid of tetramethyl ammonium hydroxide to help dissolving H2BDC had also been demonstrated as a facile purification step [51].
2.2.1.3. Microwave/ultrasound-assisted synthesis. Except the structures, the particle size of MOF-based materials has nonnegligible effect on the properties. Controlling the gradients of solute concentration and reaction temperature can greatly influence the particle size of the materials [52,53]. In microwave/ultrasound-assisted synthesis, a substrate solution mixture is transferred to a Teflon vessel placed in the microwave unit and heated at the set temperature or to a horn-type Pyrex reactor fitted to a sonicator bar with an adjustable power output [54,55]. The microwave/ultrasound are beneficial for not only the construction of the framework of the MOFs but also the decrease of particle size and size distribution,
tion of Cu(NO3)2, a bottom of H2BDC and the intermediate layer. (b) Atomic-force printed with permission from Ref. [45]. Copyright 2015 Nature Publishing Group.
because rapid and uniform heating by microwave/ultrasound lead to high nucleation rate and hence the quick consumption of the reactants to prevent further growth of the particles. Besides, the growth of the nuclei is also hindered by the high cooling rate of the hot spots resulting from acoustic cavitation [56–58]. However, fine-tuning the shape of the MOF nanoparticles by the microwave/ ultrasound remains a challenge [59].
2.2.1.4. Electrochemical synthesis. In the electrochemical process, the metal ions are continuously generated by the anodic dissolution and react with the dissolved linkers in the reaction medium. The electrochemical synthesis was proved an effective way to develop thin films on the electrodes [60]. Recently, the electrochemical synthesis of MOFs has aroused great interest because this method could control the crystal growth by not only modulating the concentration of metal ion in solution but also controlling the metal oxidation state by regulating the current intensity. Electrochemical synthesis has the advantages of mild synthesis conditions, short synthesis time and controlled reaction rate [48,61]. The flower-like morphology of MOF-5 synthesized by electrochemical method significantly differed from that of the regular cubic MOF5 (Fig. 4) [62,63]. The addition of ionic liquid 1-butyl-3methylimidazole (BMIM) promoted an ordered arrangement of the Br- and directed the Zn2+ crystalized in the position parallel to BMIM with the assistance from the linker and the electric field.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. MOF-based composites
sections.text:
Combining nanoparticle and MOF into a singular material of nanoparticle/MOF composite could produce unusual property that the individual components alone may not possess. The major synthetic methods for nanoparticle/MOF composites aimed for lithium storage application are summarized as follow.
2.2.2.1. Direct synthesis. The direct reaction of the MOF with the raw materials for the nanoparticle is an effective and facile approach to prepare nanoparticle/MOF composites. A versatile and effective methodology was demonstrated to synthesize Fe2O3@MOF composite. Five MOFs, MOF-74, UTSA-74, Mg(DHT) (DMF)2, UiO-66(OH)2, and UiO-66(OH), were slowly added to the solution of FeCl3 in H2O at room temperature, giving solid samples of Fe2O3@MOF-74, Fe2O3@UTSA-74, Fe2O3@Mg(DHT)(DMF)2, Fe2O3@UiO-66(OH)2 and Fe2O3@ UiO-66(OH) composites, respectively. An ‘enrichment-nucleation-growth’ mechanism was proposed to illustrate the synthetic process. The surface of the MOFs contains regular and free phenolate oxygen atoms from the ligands, leading to ‘phenol-Fe3+’ coordination interactions. The spontaneous enrichment of Fe3+ on MOF surface would accelerate the hydrolysis of Fe(III) to generate the nucleation and further growth of Fe2O3 for the final Fe2O3@MOF composite [64].
A nanocomposite based on polyoxometalates-based MOFs (POMOFs)/reduced graphene oxide (RGO) for LIBs was developed. Firstly, L-ascorbic acid and H5PMo10V2O40 were dissolved in H2O, following the addition of Cu(OAc)2 H2O (OAc = acetate) and GO with continuous stirring. 1 M HCl was added to adjust the pH to 3.5. After the dropwise addition of H3BTC in alcohol, the mixture was refluxed for 12 h, leading to the formation of POMOFs/RGO. The obtained nanocomposites combined the advantages of the multi-electron redox behavior of POMs, the high electronic conductivity of RGO and the open frameworks of MOFs, exhibiting superior lithium storage properties and excellent cycling performance [65].
2.2.2.2. Chemical vapor deposition method. Chemical vapor deposition (CVD) refers to a solvent-free process where a solid material is deposited from a vapor by a chemical reaction occurring on or in the vicinity of a normally heated substrate surface [66]. This method usually deals with volatile precursors and supporters with high thermal stability, thus enabling particularly high loading levels. The CVD technique was employed for the construction of metal decorated MOF composite (M@MOF). Generally, MOF was employed as the supporting material and was exposed to the vapor of the guest metal in a well-sealed Schlenk tube. As the reaction proceed, guest metals could be embedded into the MOFs in a few minutes. Long reaction time could allow a homogenous composite. In 2005, the CVD method was firstly employed for the synthesis of Au/Pd/Cu@MOF-5, [67] followed by a series studies of M@MOF composites to date [68].
In addition to the M@MOF composites, the preparation of other types of nanoparticle/MOF composites has also been developed by CVD. In 2014, a straightforward surface coating technique was developed. Using urea solid as precursor, a thin N-doped carbon layer was deposited on the porous Li2C8H4O4 electrode by CVD method, as shown in Fig. 5. The N-doped carbon coated porous electrode exhibited a unique morphology and excellent electrochemical properties [69].
2.2.2.3. Solid-state reaction. The solid-state reaction by grinding the raw materials is a solvent-free method to introduce nanoparticles into porous materials [70]. The homogeneous encapsulation of Si nanostructures into MOF matrix has advantages for the electrode materials. The assembly of MOF on the nano Si surface (denoted as Si@ZIF-8) was achieved by simply grinding the starting materials of metal salts and ligands along with silicon nanoparticles with the addition of solvent initiator (Fig. 6). The embedded Si nanoparticles can provide high capacity and the MOF matrix can effectively mitigate the volume expansion of Si in the cycling process [71]. A similar mechanochemical synthetic approach of preparing ZIF-8 nanoparticles coated with a series of hydroxyl, pyrrolyl and/or
emical approach. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [62]. Copyright 2014 Royal sion from Ref. [63]. Copyright 2006 Wiley-VCH.
carboxyl functionalized organic compounds (chitosan, glucose, citric acid, pyrrole, and b-cyclodextrin, etc.) was reported, which were further pyrolyzed and employed as anode active materials for LIBs [72].
2.2.2.4. Solvothermal method. The solvothermal method, based on the direct one-pot reaction upon heating treatments under pressure in a closed environment, is a useful way to load nanoparticles onto a MOF carrier. A Fe-MOF/RGO composite synthesized through solvothermal method has been reported. Firstly, RGO was added into DMF and stirred to obtain a well-dispersed solution. Then, H2BDC, FeCl3 6H2O, and acetic acid were added and the solution
was ultrasonicated for 0.5 h. Following that, the solution was heated in a Teflon vessel at 150 C for 2 h to obtain the Fe-MOF/ RGO composite. The combined advantages of high capacity of the MOFs and admirable electrical conductivity of the RGO contributed to an improved electrochemical performance as electrode materials in LIBs (Fig. 7) [73].
In order to further enhance the reversible capacity and thermal stability of the Li-rich layered oxide Li(Li0.17Ni0.20Co0.05Mn0.58)O2, an effective surface modification method by a Mn-based MOF with oxygen adsorbing ability was proposed. Li(Li0.17Ni0.20Co0.05Mn0.58) O2 was slowly added in the mixture of DMF-ethanol–water containing MnCl2 4H2O and 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid, then the mixture was heated in a Teflon vessel at 80 C for 2 h. After the surface modification, the crystalline structure of the Li-rich layered oxide remained undestroyed; Moreover, the morphology and grain size are almost unchanged. From transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images, an amorphous MOF layer with a thickness of 2 3 nm was found to be uniformly coated on the surface of Li (Li0.17Ni0.20Co0.05Mn0.58)O2 [74].

sections.heading: 2.2.3. MOF-derived materials
sections.text:
MOFs as sacrificial or template materials to obtain nanomaterials have found great success in recent years [25–28]. The superiority of MOF-derived nanomaterials for EES in comparison with other nanomaterials synthesized by traditional methods has been well demonstrated. Particular interest was given to tailoring the composition, shape, size, porosity and surface area of the resulted nanomaterials for enhanced electrochemical properties. Thermally-induced solid-state conversion is the main approach for MOF-derived materials and allow large scale production [75,76]. Depending on the compositions and structures of MOFs, MOFs have been triumphantly utilized for MOs, nanostructured carbon, and MO@C composites [77–79].
2.2.3.1. MOF-derived MOs. To improve the electrochemical performance, high surface area and suitable pore size are essential for nanosized MOs, which afford enough active sites for Li+ intercalation and facilitate electrolyte flux at high rates. Thermolysis of MOFs in controlled environments can produce MOs with desired structures and tuned porosity [80,81]. The high surface area Fe2O3 (200–400 m2 g 1) derived from Prussian blue (PB, {Fe4[Fe(CN)6]3}) has been reported [82]. The surface areas of these Fe2O3 were varied by the particle size of PB. As the particle size increased, the surface area of the resulted Fe2O3 decreased. Nanosized Co3O4 with a particle size of 25 nm was synthesized from a Co-MOF ([Co3(NDC)3(DMF)4]n, NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate) under optimized condition [83]. The controlled synthesis of hematite (a-Fe2O3) or magnetite (Fe3O4) rods using Fe-MIL-88B precursor (MIL: Materiaux de l’Institut Lavoisier/ Materials from the Lavoisier Institute) was demonstrated [84].
printed with permission from Ref. [73]. Copyright 2016 Royal Society of Chemistry.
Heating Fe-MIL-88B directly in air would exclusively generate aFe2O3 nanorods. The two-step procedure comprising calcination in air and the following heat treatment in inert atmosphere turned the initially-formed Fe2O3 into Fe3O4. The mixed-valence CuO/ Cu2O nanostructure was fabricated by calcination of [Cu3(BTC)2]n at 350 C, exhibiting a superior capacity of 740 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 as anode material for LIBs [85]. Moreover, MOFs containing different metal centers are potential sacrificial materials for AB2O4 nanostructures. For example, by using a so-called ‘escape-by-crafty scheme’ method, spinel zinc manganite (ZnMn2O4) and nickel manganite (NiMn2O4) nanoplate were synthesized (Fig. 8) [86]. This strategy used ZnMn2-ptcda and NiMn2-ptcda (ptcda = 3,4,9,10-perylene tetracarboxylic dianhydride) as precursors favored the formation of highly crystallized spinel ZnMn2O4 and NiMn2O4 in comparison with the traditional co-precipitation method. This was mainly because the uniformly distributed metal ions and high crystallinity of the MOF precursor. The spinel structure formed at temperatures above 450 C.
Intense interest has been attracted by the development of MOx with hollow core–shell structures due to their superior electrochemical properties [87]. An interesting example of a porous Co3O4 nanocage was synthesized by utilizing a facile way based on Kirkendall effect, via heating treatment of a PB analogue (Co3[Co(CN)6]2) at 400 C, to form truncated nanocage. Because of the volume loss and release of internally produced CO2 and NxOy during the non-equilibrium inter-diffusion process, Co3O4 nanocage with porous shells was formed, which exhibited superior electrochemical properties for anode material of LIBs [88]. Oxidative decomposition of PBmicrocube can afford Fe2O3microboxwith hierarchical shells [89]. The shape of the resultant microbox depended significantly on the thermolytic temperature. When the decomposition temperature was 350 C, Fe2O3 microbox was obtained. Further increasing the temperature to 550 C resulted in porous Fe2O3 microbox. When the temperature increased to 650 C, hierarchical microbox containing Fe2O3 nanoplatelets was developed.
2.2.3.2. MOF-derived carbons. As the main component of the ligands of MOFs, the removal of metallic species during or after the carbonization of MOFs can produce high surface area carbons [90–93]. The carbonization temperatures, the compositions and structures of MOFs play an important role in the resulted carbon products. It has been proved that carbonization process including decomposition of MOFs followed by the elimination of metal elements can proceed at high temperature in inert atmosphere. For instance, the thermal decomposition process of Zn-MOFs resulted in ZnO, which has a boiling point at 2360 C and hence was difficult to remove by heating in comparison with that of Zn (908 C) [94]. However, the in situ formed carbon can effectively reduce ZnO to Zn, which can vaporize at considerably low temperature [94,95].
For MOFs comprising other metals (e.g., Fe, Co, Cu) with higher boiling points than Zn, metallic species could be retained in the carbonized samples. A post-acid wash treatment would remove the metals and generate porous carbons [96].
The introduction of secondary carbon source such as furfuryl alcohol to ZIF-8 endowed the resulted carbon product with high surface area (3405 m2 g 1) and large pore volume (2.58 cm3 g 1) [97]. Another efficient strategy to achieve high surface area carbons without any secondary precursors is post-treatment of the carbon product. For instance, acid washing was employed to remove impurities after heating treatment of the mixed carbonized product and potassium hydroxide, to give carbons with surface areas over 2000 m2 g 1 [98].
The dimensionality of carbon could be controlled by different types of MOFs, to give the carbons with dimensionality varied from zero-dimensional (0D) to 3D. For example, heating treatment of ZIF-8 nanoparticles at 500 C would provide carbon nanodots, which have particle size of 2.2 nm (Fig. 9a) [99]. Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) were conducted by calcinating the Ni-MOF ([Ni3(BTC)2 12H2O]n) at 500 C for 20 h (Fig. 9b) [100]. The calcination of a ZIF-7/glucose composite in the Ar atmosphere produced graphene-like carbon nanosheets (Fig. 9c) [101]. The carbonization of ZIF-8 with both micro- and mesopores, followed by KOH treatment, afforded 3D hierarchically porous carbon exhibiting a high surface area of 2972 m2 g 1 and excellent EES performance (Fig. 9d) [102]. In addition, the effect of different types of organic ligands upon the properties of the carbons was also studied. A series of Zn-MOFs, such as MOF-2 ([(H2NEt2)2[Zn3(BDC)4] 3DEF]), MOF-5 ([Zn4O(BDC)3]) and Zn-BTC ([Zn3(BTC)2(DMSO)4], DMSO = dimethylsulfoxide), were selected as representative MOFs. MOF-5 with the highest aromaticity provided the highest surface area carbon product, suggesting that the surface area decreased with the decreasing aromaticity of the ligands of the MOFs [40].
2.2.3.3. MOF-derived MO/C composites. In a well-controlled condition, MOFs could serve as suitable precursors for MO/C composites, which would prevent the agglomeration of MO nanoparticles and facilitate the in situ generated carbon to coat MO particles with large pore volume, high surface areas and a uniform dispersion, which are favorable to the electrochemical properties as electrode materials for LIBs [103]. The 3D carbon decorated ZnO quantum dots (ZnO/C QDs, 3.5 nm) were derived from MOF-5 through a controlled calcination process [15]. The original morphology was undestroyed when MOF-5 was heated, despite some surface cracks developed due to the ligand decomposition. The ultra-small ZnO QDs homogeneously dispersed in porous carbon was responsible for the long life-time anode material for LIBs [104].
Furthermore, the effects of metal reduction potential on determining the generation of MO/C nanomaterials from MOF
zinc manganese-3,4,9,10-perylene tetracarboxylic dianhydride (ZnMn2-ptcda) as a f. [86]. Copyright 2012 Royal Society of Chemistry.
precursors have been studied. As shown in Fig. 10, MOFs were converted to carbon supported MO nanoparticles upon thermolysis if the comprising metals have reduction potentials lower than 0.27 V, which is mainly because the metal ions with lower reduction potentials are difficult to reduce to the zero-oxidation state. When the reduction potential of metals are equal or higher than 0.27 V, MOFs can easily be transformed to carbon coated pure metal nanoparticles [93].

sections.heading: 3. MOF-related materials as electrodes for rechargeable lithium ion batteries
sections.text:
Over the past decade, electrode materials for LIBs have been rapidly developed for low cost, fast charging/discharging rate, high capacity, long cycling life, and environmental benignancy [105].
Based on the features of MOFs, the research of MOFs as electrode materials for LIBs is becoming a hot issue. The structural diversity and flexibility of MOFs can be well controlled at the molecular level, allowing the ligands to be redox-active, to be processed efficiently, and to be prepared from renewable resources. In addition, their porosity of MOFs can lead to large lithium-ion accommodation space and suitable lithium-ion pathway. On the other hand, MOF-based nanomaterials can inherit the features from MOFs, conquering the disadvantages of low electronic conductivity and enhancing chemical stabilities for EES applications [106,107]. In this part, we will summarize three main approaches to develop new electrode materials based on MOFs: (1) pristine MOFs directly used as electrode materials (Table 1); (2) nanoparticle/MOF composites as electrode materials (Table 2); (3) MOF-derived materials as electrode materials (Table 3).

sections.heading: 3.1. Pristine MOFs
sections.text: MOFs constructed by metal ions or clusters and organic linkers can offer redox-active metal centers and organic ligands to accommodate multiple electrons, nanosized cavities and open channels to provide pathways for electrolytes to easily access and Li+ to transport, large void spaces and excellent structural flexibility to buffer volume expansions, resulting in high reversible capacities and in turn superior energy densities, along with good cyclabilities [108,109].

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Anode materials
sections.text:
MOF-177 ([ZnO4(BTB)2](DEF)m(H2O)n, H3BTB = 4,40,400-benzene1,3,5-triyl-tri-benzoic acid) was the first example of MOFs as anode material for LIBs. It showed a relatively high initial discharge capacity ( 400 mA h g 1) but much lower reversible capacities for the subsequent discharge–charge processes [110]. This capacity degradation was caused by the destroyed MOF structure after lithium storage in the discharge process, leading to a poor cycling performance of MOF-177. This pioneering work shed a preliminary light upon the lithium-storage study of MOF-based anode materials for LIBs and encouraged researchers to explore new MOFs with better performance.
For the conversion-type anode materials, regeneration of the MOF during the cycling plays a vital role for the lithium storage performance and cyclability. Zn3(HCOO)6 with diamondoid structure was investigated as a conversion-type anode material [111]. After slightly decline, the reversible capacity finally stabilized at 560 mA h g 1 over 60 cycles between 0.005 and 3.0 V (Fig. 11).
e generation of MO/C nanomaterials. When the metal reduction potential is above osphere; When the metal reduction potential is below 0.27 V, only MOs can be emistry.
The Coulombic efficiency was >97% after 10 cycles. Analysis of the electrochemical results along with ex situ powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR), and TEM indicated a ‘conversion’ reaction mechanism and the regeneration of Zn3(HCOO)6 during the electrochemical cycling in this system, suggesting that Zn3(HCOO)6 framework reacted reversibly with lithium through conversion reaction. During the charging process, Zn3(HCOO)6 reacted with Li+, to form Zn nanoparticles and in turn Li-Zn alloy, which is responsible for the superior lithium storage properties. MOFs can be regenerated during the discharging process, with alloy gradually converting back into metallic Zn, which then forming the zinc formate. The reactions are as follows:
Zn3(HCOO)6 + 6Liþ + 6e $ 3Zn + 6HCOOLi ð1Þ
3Zn + 3Liþ + 3e $ 3LiZn ð2Þ A diamondoid-structured ([Cu2(BDC)4]n) was synthesized by a scalable electrochemical route, which had the ability to reversibly storage Li+ [112]. The initial discharge capacity was 227 mA h g 1 at 24 mA g 1, which was almost 95% of the calculated capacity. Other MOFs were also studied, including Mn-LCP ([Mn(tfbdc) (4,40-bpy)(H2O)2]) exhibiting a specific of 390 mA h g 1 [113] and Co2(OH)2BDC of 650 mA h g 1, [114] with good cycling stabilities.
Apart from the conversion-type anode materials, the insertiontype PBAs (M3II[CoIII(CN)6]2 nH2O M = Co, Mn) allows fast intercalation/deintercalation of Li+, accompanied by the valence change of Co2+, giving rise to the specific capacity of 300 mA h g 1 with excellent rate performance [115]. Mechanism studies on the intercalation/deintercalation process showed that the electrochemical adsorption/desorption of PF6- in the electrolyte might also boosted
the redox reaction of PB [116]. The iMOF, 2,6-naphthalene dicarboxylate dilithium, has been reported as an outstanding insertion-type anode material [117]. The iMOF showed a reversible two-electron transfer process with Li+ intercalation at the voltage 0.8 V and a small volume change of 0.33%. Above all, the iMOF was employed as the anode to fabricate the first MOF-based full cell, coupling with the LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cathode. The conducted full cell exhibited high cell voltage and superior specific energy/power density.
For the insertion-type anode materials, lithium storage properties can be attributed to not only variable-valence metal ions but also function groups of ligands strongly interacting with Li+. A Co-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate MOF (Co-BDC) with exceptionally impressive capacities (1090/611 mA h g 1 at 200/1000 mA g 1) accompanied by excellent rate capability was reported [118]. This superior lithium storage performance stood out from a crowd of other MOF-based anode materials. Li+ was only inserted into the organic moiety during charge–discharge processes. Ni-MOFs was also tested for anode materials. Anodes made of the as-prepared ([Ni3(OH)2(BDC)2(H2O)4] 2H2O) [119] and Ni-Me4bpz ([Ni(Me4bpz)2(Cl)2]n) [120] showed reversible capacities of 620 and 120 mA h g 1 at 100 and 50 mA g 1, respectively, after 100 cycles.
Another approach for enhanced lithium storage capacities of MOFs is the introduction of redox-active sites on both metal centers and the ligands. Two isostructural POM-based MOFs which have redox-active sites on both metal centers and ligands with diamond topology, NENU-506 ((TBA)3[PMoV8MoVI4 O38(OH)2Zn4(IN)2], IN = isonicotinic acid, TBA+ = tetrabutylammonium ion) and NENU507((TBA)3[PMoV8MoVI4 O38(OH)2Zn4(PBA)2] H2O, HPBA = 4-(pyridin4-yl) benzoic acid), were reported [121]. They showed not only combined advantages derived from the synergistic effect of POMs
and MOFs, delivering superior chemical and thermal stabilities. Above all, NENU-507 showed an impressive specific capacity of 640 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 at the 100th cycle as the anode material of LIBs.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Cathode materials
sections.text:
Due to the porous structure, uncoordinated metal sites and functional organic linkers, MOFs can also be used as cathode for LIBs based on reversible lithiation/delithiation reactions. The varied metal oxidation states in MOFs play critical role in the reversible lithium storage process without MOF destruction. Previous
work has proved that one effective approach to overcome the irreversible lithiation/delithiation process is to employ MOFs with mixed-valence metal centers to obtain higher M–O bond stability. Férey group synthesized [FeIII(OH)0.8F0.2(bdc)] (MIL-53(Fe)) and tested it as cathode material [122]. The electrochemical cell had the water-free phase mixed with 15 wt% carbon as working electrode and metallic Li as the counter electrode. The gravimetric and volumetric capacity (75 and 140 mA h g 1, respectively) of MIL-53(Fe) solid towards lithium were not high, mixed-valence MOFs are becoming a reality and opening new opportunities for cathode materials of LIBs.
MIL-53(Fe) exhibited better electrochemical reversibility than MIL-68(Fe) (FeOH(BDC)) [123]. However, the induction of HF in the preparation of process limited the mass production of MIL-53 (Fe). To solve this problem, MIL-101(Fe) (Fe3-(m3-O)Cl (H2O)2(BDC)3) was studied as an cathode candidate, of which the calculated capacity is 108 mA h g 1, with 1Li/Fe. MIL-101(Fe) undergone structurally reversible intercalation reactions, with the Fe3+/Fe2+ redox-active couples [124]. In repeated charge–discharge process, a decrease in reversible lithium storage capacity was observed. MIL-101(Fe) accommodated 0.62Li/Fe at a voltage of 2.0 V via initial lithiation (Fig. 12), of which the value was comparable to MIL-53(Fe) ( 0.62Li/Fe at 1.5 V) but higher than MIL-68 (Fe) ( 0.35Li/Fe at 1.5 V). The initial Coulombic efficiency of MIL-
Fig. 12. (a) Voltage profiles (b) and differential capacity (dQ/dV) at the current density Coulombic efficiency rested between discharge (C/20) and charge (C/20) for different a Society of Chemistry.
101(Fe) (79%) was lower than that of MIL-53(Fe) ( 97%) but close to that of MIL-68(Fe) ( 79%). On account of the irreversibility, MIL101(Fe) exhibited very low capacity retention, accommodating only 0.37Li/Fe by the 5th cycle.
The introduction of multiple redox centers can provide an effective method for enhanced gravimetric capacity. A porous MOF offering redox-active site on both metal node and organic linkers, Cu(2,7-AQDC) (2,7-H2AQDC = 2,7-anthraquinonedicarboxylic acid) was synthesized and used as a cathode of LIBs [125]. In cyclic performance test within 1.7–4.0 V, the metal nodes and anthraquinone groups showed synergistic redox activities, affording a capacity of 147 mA h g 1 in the first cycle, however, this capacity rapidly declined and stabilized at 105 mA h g 1 in the 50th cycle.
Lithium storage performances of MOF-based cathodes consisting of other metals have also been explored. K2.5[(VO)2(HPO4)1.5 (PO4)0.5(C2O4)] was synthesized by the Vittal group, in which K+ reversibly exchanged with Li+ within 2.5–4.6 V, showing a specific capacity of 66 mA h g 1 at 40 mA g 1 in the 60th cycle [126]. They also developed the Li2(VO)2(HPO4)2(C2O4) MOF showing reversible capacities of 80 mA h g 1 at 0.1C and 47 mA h g 1 at 4C, respectively, after 25 cycles [127].

sections.heading: 3.2. MOF-based composites
sections.text: Directly utilized as electrode materials for LIBs, MOFs still have limitations such as low electrical conductivity, poor capacity retention, incomplete electrode reactions and poor cycling performance [128,129]. To solve the problem, MOF-based composites have been explored for alternative electrode materials over the recent decades. Each component in the composites possesses unique function, and the combination in the composites show synergistic effects of the independent counterparts by conquering the disadvantages and maintaining their unique functions, affording improved electrochemical properties.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Anode materials
sections.text:
a-Fe2O3 is an important family as anode materials for LIBs and hence systematic investigation on the electrochemical

performance of a series of Fe2O3@MOF composites, including Fe2O3@MOF-74, Fe2O3@UTSA-74, Fe2O3@Mg(DHT)(DMF)2, Fe2O3@UiO-66(OH)2, and Fe2O3@UiO-66(OH), were performed. As shown in Fig. 13, in the 45th cycle, a specific capacity of 650 mA h g 1 was obtained for Fe2O3@UTSA-74, close to the best value of Fe2O3-based anode materials due to the thin nanosheet Fe2O3 on the surface of UTSA-74 that could facilitate the electrolyte penetration and lithium transportation [64]. Moreover, the microporous-mesoporous structure of Fe2O3@UTSA-74 can also efficiently mitigate the volume expansion in the following cycling process. Further studies on both Fe2O3@MOF-74 and Fe2O3@UTSA74 with high loadings and regular arrays of Fe2O3 particles on MOF surface exhibited significantly improved cycling performance compared to Fe2O3@Mg(DHT)(DMF)2, Fe2O3@UiO-66(OH)2, and Fe2O3@UiO-66(OH) because of the low load of bulk Fe2O3 in the Fe2O3@MOF composites.
Due to the compositions and formation mechanism, MOFs can be grown on electrically conducting substrates, for example, graphene and carbon cloth, which is proved an effective method to improve the electrochemical performance. For example, Fe-MOF/ RGO composites were successfully obtained through a feasible solvothermal synthesis and employed as anode materials [73]. The Fe-MOF/RGO (5%) composites delivered impressive specific capacity (2259 mA h g 1 at 500 mA g 1), high rate performance and extraordinary cycling activity (maintaining a reversible capacity of 1010 mA h g 1 at the 200th cycle). These outstanding lithium storage properties can mainly be attributed to the combined advantages of MOFs with high theoretical capacity and RGO with superior electroconductibility. The capacities of MOF-based composites can be enhanced by heteroatom-doping. Zhang et al. reported N-doped carbon coated Li2C8H4O4 microspheres as advanced anode materials [69]. The initial Coulombic efficiency, the rate performance and the cycling performance were quickly elevated up because of the coating layer compared to the original Li2C8H4O4 sample. Wei. et al. have demonstrated the utilization of PMG-3 (Polyoxometalates, MOFs and RGO nanocomposite) as anode material, which showed excellent electrochemical properties due to the synergistic effects of multiple redox centers of POMs, admirable electroconductivity of RGO and open frameworks of MOFs that can mitigate the volumetric changes and afford improved cycling performance. In comparison with pristine MOFs and the POMs-based anodes previously reported, the PMG-3 nanocomposite showed the highest specific capacity of 1075 mA h g 1 and almost 100% capacity retentions both at 2000 and 3000 mA g 1 in the 400th cycle [65].

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Cathode materials
sections.text: Li-rich layered oxides have aroused great interest as cathode materials of LIBs for their superior lithium storage properties. To further improve the lithium storage properties and thermal stabilities of the Li-rich Li(Li0.17Ni0.20Co0.05Mn0.58)O2, an efficient strategy of surface modification by Mn-based MOF with stable architecture, large surface area and pore size, was developed. In this work, Mn-based MOF absorbed parts of O2 originated from oxidation of O2– in the Li(Li0.17Ni0.20Co0.05Mn0.58)O2 host lattice during the process charging to above 4.5 V. In addition, the structure of Li(Li0.17Ni0.20Co0.05Mn0.58)O2 was stabilized by interconnected metal ions and organic linkers. The Li (Li0.17Ni0.20Co0.05Mn0.58)O2 with the Mn-based MOF modification presented superior specific capacity (324 mA h g 1 at 0.1C), admirable Coulombic efficiency in the first cycle (91%), excellent cycling and rate performance. The surface modification by MOFs shed light on a new perspective for further enhanced electrochemical properties of Li-rich layered oxides as cathode of LIBs [74].

sections.heading: 3.3. MOF-derived materials
sections.text: MOFs with varied structures could be ideal precursors for functional hybrid materials for electrochemical applications. MOFderived MOs, carbon and MO@C composites with modulated porosity, retained redox-active center and high electroconductivity, have been well studied as electrode materials in the field of LIBs [77–79,130].

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Anode materials
sections.text:
3.3.1.1. MOF-derived MOs. Because of the compositions and structures of MOFs, heating MOFs in controlled environments could provide different kinds of MOs. In this way, the MOF-derived MOs always have porous nanostructures that could provide pathways for electrolytes and transportation of lithium ions, large void spaces to buffer volume changes and lower densities to attain significant loading capacities, favoring the enhanced capacity, improved rate capability and prolonged cycle life. The morphologies and functionalities of the MOs could be fine-tuned by not only MOF precursors but also the controlled conditions, which is crucial for enhanced electrochemical properties [130,131].
MO nanostructures with high surface areas allow multi-lithium intercalation and lead to excellent electrochemical performance for LIBs. For example, using MIL-88(Fe) as the sacrificial template, a spindle-like porous a-Fe2O3 was prepared via a two-step calcination, which exhibited a significantly impressive capacity of 911 mA h g 1 in the 50th cycle at 0.2 C and an excellent rate performance up to 10 C rate [132]. In contrast, the a-Fe2O3 nanospindles obtained via one step heating treatment in air demonstrated a capacity of 1024 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 and superior cycling stability. The capacity retention is 90% in the 40th cycle [133]. However, the rate performance of the one-step-yielded a-Fe2O3 was inferior to the two-step-synthesized one due to a much higher surface area of a-Fe2O3 obtained via the two-step synthesis method. A porous anatase TiO2 with a surface area of 220 m2 g 1 was developed as anode material of LIBs. The high surface area can facilitate rapid Li+ diffusion and buffer the volumetric change during the cycling processes. Reversible capacities of 166, 106 and 71 mA h g 1 at 1 C, 5 C and 10 C, respectively, were retained in the 500th cycle [134].
Mixed metal MOs were also conducted via MOF-template strategy. A facile synthetic route for Mn1.8Fe1.2O4 nanocubes was reported by annealing Mn3[Fe(CN)6]2 nH2O nanocubes at 450 C [135]. During the calcination process, the distance between the intrinsically monodispersed Fe and Mn shortened, promoting the production of porous Mn1.8Fe1.2O4 nanocubes. The capacity of the Mn1.8Fe1.2O4 nanocubes was 827 mA h g 1 in the 60th cycle at
200 mA g 1. For enhanced electrochemical performance, Huang et al. developed hierarchical porous core–shell NiFe2O4@TiO2 nanorods via calcination of core–shell Fe2Ni MIL-88@TiO2 nanorods [136]. The core–shell NiFe2O4@TiO2 nanorods showed a significantly high reversible capacity of 1034 mA h g 1 in the 100th cycle at 100 mA g 1, much higher than that of pristine NiFe2O4 nanorods. The synergistic effects of each individual counterpart in the composites and the porous hollow architectures contributed to the superior electrochemical performance. In addition, NiFe2O4/Fe2O3 nanotubes [137], CoFe2O4 nanocubes [138], NiCo2O4/NiO dodecahedron [139] and Fe2O3@NiCo2O4 nanocages [140] were also conducted from a variety of hybrid MOFs, delivering impressive capacities and rate capabilities.
The hollow structures can afford high surface areas, large void spaces to buffer volume expansions, low densities and significant loading capacities that are extremely important for anode materials for LIBs. Hollow Co3O4 dodecahedra with controlled interior from ZIF-67 was successfully obtained [141]. The obtained ballin-dodecahedron Co3O4 exhibited a specific capacity of 1335 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 in the 100th cycle. The rate performance was also impressive with a retained capacity of 493 mA h g 1 at 1500 mA g 1. Another ZIF-67-derived Co3O4 hollow dodecahedra exhibiting excellent electrochemical performance was developed [142]. The high symmetric Co3O4 hollow dodecahedra was obtained through the thermal treatment of ZIF67 at 350 C in N2 and a subsequent pyrolysis process under air atmosphere. The as-prepared Co3O4 retained a specific capacity of 780 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 in the 100th cycle. A successful derivation of porous hollow Co3O4 nanocages from the PBA, Co3[Co(CN)6]2, has also been reported (Fig. 14a) [88]. The resulted Co3O4 nanocages showed a capacity of 1500 mA h g 1 at 300 mA g 1 and an excellent rate performance and cycling stability (Fig. 14b). Moreover, the electrical conductivity, structural and mechanical properties of Co3O4 can be enhanced through growing the MOs on electro-conductive substrates. For instance, ZIF-67 derived porous Co3O4 nanosheets on 3D nickel foam, referred to
as Co3O4/3DNF, maintained a specific capacity of 976 mA h g 1 at 5000 mA g 1 in the 500th cycle, which stood out from the previously reported anode materials [143].
3.3.1.2. MOF-derived carbon. On account of the well-defined architectures and high surface areas, MOFs can be used as excellent templates for developing carbon materials with desired inherent properties. A 3D porous carbon derivative from MOF-5 was reported for LIBs [144]. The obtained 3D carbon exhibited an impressive reversible capacity of 1015 mA h g 1 in the 100th cycle and an excellent cycling performance. Incorporation of nitrogen atoms into carbon materials could provide abundant active sites and strengthened interaction between the carbon materials and Li+. A successful derivation of high-level N-doped microporous carbon for LIBs was prepared via direct heating treatment of the N-doped ZIF-8 [145]. The optimized N-containing material (N content: 17.72 wt%) showed a significantly admirable capacity of 2132 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 in the 50th cycle. The CV curves after the first cycle were almost overlapped, manifesting the superior cycle stability of the N-doped microporous carbon material (Fig. 15).
3.3.1.3. MOF-derived MO/C composites. Although MOs usually have high capacities for EES, they are unstable due to their huge volumetric changes upon cycling. Introducing a secondary species can buffer the volume expansion and reserve the primary superior electrochemical properties. Porous carbon matrixes with high surface areas have been considered excellent stabilizer upon the cycling process. Considering that MOFs would produce high surface area carbon upon thermal treatments, optimized calcination will achieve admirably porous MO/C composites [146].
The particular advantage of using MOFs for MO/C composites is the generation of uniformly dispersed carbon coated MO particles. For example, the derivation of ZnO QDs (3.5 nm) with uniform carbon coatings from controlled thermal decomposition of MOF-5 was reported (Fig. 16) [15]. The composite exhibited a high surface area of 513 m2 g 1, with high dispersion of ZnO QDs, to show a specific capacity of 1200 mA h g 1 at 75 mA g 1 due to the synergistic contribution of both ZnO and carbon. For other porous carbon coated ZnO materials as anode materials, ZnO@C showed a capacity of 750 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 [147] and ZnO@MWCNTs of 419 mA h g 1 at 200 mA g 1 [148]. For enhanced electrochemical performance, Co-containing ZnO@C (CZO@C) has been constructed, exhibiting a reversible capacity of 725 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 in the 50th cycle [149]. They also constructed Co-containing ZnO coated by carbon/carbon nanotube (CZO@C/CNT). CZO@C/CNT achieved an improved specific capacity of 758 mA h g 1 in the 50th cycle at 100 mA g 1 when used as anode of LIBs [150]. Fe2O3 nanoparticles coated by N-containing hollow carbon sphere shells (Fe2O3@N-C) were fabricated via pyrolysis of Fe-ZIF at 620 C, exhibiting a capacity of 1573 mA h g 1 in the 50th cycle at 0.1C [151]. Core/shell ZnO/ZnCo2O4/C composites (ZnO as a core and ZnCo2O4 as a shell) were also proved to be attractive anode materials of LIBs, showing an admirable capacity of 669 mA h g 1 in the 250th cycle at 500 mA g 1 [152]. A novel ZnO-ZnFe2O4@C composite was developed and distinguished as an anode of LIBs [153]. At optimized condition, a specific capacity of 1390 mA h g 1 at 500 mA g 1 was obtained. The resultant excellent electrochemical results were derived from the same molar ratio of Zn with Fe and the embedded nanoparticles in carbon matrix with hollow spaces helped to accommodate the volumetric changes and maintain the electrical connectivity integrity.
Thermal decomposition of MOFs grown on electrically conducting substrates is an effective method for fabricating high energy anode materials, benefiting from both the nanostructure of MOFs and strengthened interactions with the conductive substrate. By
calcination of MIL-88-Fe grown on 3DGN (3D graphene networks), Fe2O3/3DGN was prepared. The Fe2O3/3DGN composite demonstrated an impressive capacity of 864 mA h g 1 in the 50th cycle, which was extremely superior to pure Fe2O3 (24.3 mA h g 1), benefiting from the excellent electrical conductivity of 3DGN (Fig. 17) [154]. Moreover, graphene-supported well-defined Co3O4 nanoparticles were constructed by calcination of GO/ZIF-67 [155]. The nanoparticles retained an excellent lithium storage capacity of 714 mA h g 1 in the 200th cycle at 5000 mA g 1. A sandwich-like structure with RGO coated ZnCo2O4-ZnO-C polyhedrons on Ni foam was developed, which revealed remarkable lithium storage capacity of 1184 mA h g 1 in the 150th cycle at 100 mA g 1 as anode for LIBs [156].
We have proposed an effective method to obtain monodispersed SnO2 particles within 3D connected carbon networks (SnO2@C) by dexterously combining the porous structure and adsorption property of HKUST-1 [157]. The anode material exhib-
ited an impressive capacity of 900 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 in the 50th cycle and maintained a high capacity value of 880 mA h g 1 even in the 200th cycle. We also adopted a similar synthetic approach and obtained N-doped-carbon-coated SnO2 nanoparticles (SOC-3) [158]. The obtained N-doped-carbon-coated SnO2 particles with a uniform dispersion can significantly relieve the volumetric changes upon the cycling process. When used as anode material, SOC-3 maintained an admirable capacity of 1032 mA h g 1 at 100 mA g 1 in the 200th cycle and a capacity of 600 mA h g 1 at 500 mA g 1, with a Coulombic efficiency of 99%.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Cathode materials
sections.text:
AMOF-derived NiS material was evaluated as a cathode for LIBs. By using MOF-74 (Ni) as precursors, nanosized Ni particles of 5–10 nm were firstly prepared in carbon matrix, followed by a transformation into NiS via an in-situ reaction. The obtained MOF-derived NiS showed a specific capacity of 300 mA h g 1 at
60 mA g 1 over 100 cycles, which was proved to be much higher than that of bare NiS (100 mA h g 1 at 60 mA g 1 after 20 cycles) [159].
Cathode material of hollow CoS nanoparticles incorporated in graphitic carbon nanocages (HCSP GCC) were conducted through a facile top-down method using room-temperature obtained ZIF67 as the template. The as-obtained HCSP GCC possessed the cooperative behavior for ultrasmall hollow building units, porous hollow interior in the structure, and compliant conductive carbon matrices. By virtue of these distinct advantages, the HCSP GCC cathode exhibited impressive energy density (707 Wh kg 1), excellent rate performance (capacities of 536, 489, 438, 393, 345, and 278 mA h g 1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10C, respectively) and admirable cycle stability ( 74% capacity retention in the 150th cycle at 1C) within 1.0–3.0 V [160].
A high energy MDA (MOF-derived alumina)-coated cathode material LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 (NCM-622) was synthesized by using NH2-MIL-53 as precursor for the production of MDA coatings. The obtained NCM-622 had an amorphous structure, with MDAcoatings uniformly dispersed on the surface. At an optimized MDA content of 2.5 wt%, NCM-622 showed improved capacities of 214 mA h g 1 and 196 mA h g 1 at 0.2 C and 1 C, respectively, with a capacity loss of 7.3% in the 100th cycle at 1 C. Even at 5 C and 10 C, the capacities still approached 168 mA h g 1 and 150 mA h g 1, respectively. It was demonstrated that the superior structural stability and electrochemical kinetics of MDA-coated NCM-622 played a critical role in the enhanced electrochemical properties [161].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions and perspectives
sections.text:
Lithium ion batteries have made significant advances since the last three decades as EES technologies for portable applications. The research for high-performance electrode materials has been considered as one of the top priorities for researchers. The advantages of well-designed structure, well-defined pore structure, high surface area, low densities and various functional groups make MOFs as highly attractive candidates for lithium storage materials. We have presented an overview of the recent progresses from the designed strategies to the targeted MOFs, MOF-based composites and MOF-derived nanostructures for their potential applications in LIBs. The details are as follows:
(1) In general, MOFs can be constructed by relatively facile and scalable methods such as direct reaction in solution, hydrothermal/solvothermal synthesis, microwave/ ultrasound-assisted synthesis and electrochemical methods.
By rationally structural design, a significant number of MOFs with tailorable compositions, structures, morphologies, and functionalities have been successfully conducted for lithium storage. By well-designed metal nodes and organic linkers, it is powerful to tune the architectures of MOFs and acquire redox-active functional groups and metal sites that can both contribute to electrochemical activity. In addition, the network of the MOF could be also conducive to enhance electrochemical properties. (2) Owing to the porous nature, MOFs can include specific guest species into their cavities to form MOF-based composites via different methods including direct synthesis, CVD, solidstate reaction and the solvothermal method. The combination in the composites shows synergistic effects of the independent counterparts by conquering the disadvantages and maintaining their unique functions, affording improved electrochemical properties. (3) MOFs have been proved to be ideal sacrificial templates to tune the compositions and morphologies of their derivates including carbon, MOs as well as MO/C composites. MOFderived MOs and carbons with high surface areas and narrow pore size distributions tend to be admirable electrode materials of LIBs with superior electrochemical properties. Furthermore, their composites by combing nanostructured redox active MOs in situ coated with carbon could improve the conductivity and facilitate lithium ion transportation.
It can be concluded that the experimental results obtained till now are truly encouraging and the MOF-related materials for the applications in LIBs have a very bright future. However, the improvements on the chemical stability and electroconductivity of pristine MOFs are still of great challenge for the EES applications. More facile approaches for the design and construction of MOFs with optimal coordination between metal nodes and organic ligands and MOF-related nanostructures ought to be explored to afford more applicable materials. Moreover, progressive characterization and theoretical calculation methods are necessary to systematically understanding the mechanisms of lithium ion storage in MOFs, MOF-based composites and MOF-derived materials. With sustained efforts devoted to these topics, there are great opportunities to achieve the practical applications of MOF-related materials in the field of LIBs.

metadata.abstractText: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are acknowledged as a new generation of porous materials and have attracted great interest because of the controllable structures, tunable properties and diverse applications for gas storage, catalysis, magnetism, sensing and drug delivery. Recently, MOFs have been proved outstanding candidates of electrochemical energy storage materials. Their chemical compositions and structures can be tuned at the molecular level and inherently porous framework can facilitate fast mass transportation. In this review, principles and strategies for the rational design of MOFs and MOFrelated nanomaterials for electrochemical energy storage are systematically summarized. Furthermore, this review is also structured to cover recent progress of MOFs and MOF-related nanomaterials and their potential applications for rechargeable lithium ion batteries. 2019 Elsevier B.V.
